introPages.title: What are auxiliary verbs?
introPages.body:
Auxiliary verbs 'help' the main verb. They form tense, passive, questions, and negatives. In Part 2, the gap often needs an auxiliary.

There are two types: primary auxiliaries (be, have, do) and modal verbs (can, could, would, will, must, should, etc.).

They always go with another verb – the main verb carries the meaning; the auxiliary carries the grammar.

introPages.title: Primary auxiliaries: be, have, do
introPages.body:
Be – forms passive and continuous: is, are, was, were, been, being. Passive: operations are carried out. Continuous: she is working.

Have – forms perfect: have, has, had. They have finished. He has left.

Do – forms questions and negatives in present/past simple: do, does, did. Do you know? Does he want to? Did they go?

introPages.title: Passive and questions
introPages.body:
Passive: subject + be + past participle. The auxiliary be must match the subject and tense: operations are carried out (plural present), the work was done (past), it has been completed (present perfect).

Questions: In present/past simple, we add do/does/did: Do you agree? Does she live here? Did they leave? Other tenses use be or have before the subject.

introPages.title: Modal verbs
introPages.body:
Modals: can, could, would, will, must, should, may, might, shall. They express possibility, ability, obligation, permission, or habit.

They are followed by the bare infinitive (no to): you should book, he can swim. No -s in third person: he can (not he cans).

Common in gaps: would not be possible, you should book, they may have left.

introPages.title: Rules for gaps
introPages.body:
• Passive? → be in the right form (is/are/was/were/been) + past participle.
  • Perfect? → have/has/had + past participle.
  • Question or negative in present/past simple? → do/does/did.
  • Modal? → check meaning (ability, obligation, possibility) and use can, would, should, etc. + bare infinitive.

mcQuiz.question: What do auxiliary verbs do?
options: Help form tense, passive, questions and negatives
Stand alone as the main verb
mcQuiz.explanation: Auxiliaries work with the main verb to form tense, passive voice, questions, and negatives.

mcQuiz.question: In operations ___ carried out, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Passive needs 'be' + past participle. 'Operations' is plural, present → are.

mcQuiz.question: Which auxiliary do we use for questions in present simple (e.g. ___ you know)?
mcQuiz.explanation: Present simple questions use do/does: Do you know? Does he know?

mcQuiz.question: Modal verbs are followed by what?
mcQuiz.explanation: Modals take the bare infinitive: can go, should book, must leave (not to go).

mcQuiz.question: Do modal verbs add -s in third person?
mcQuiz.explanation: Modals don't change: he can, she must, it would (never cans, musts).

mcQuiz.question: In they ___ finished, which auxiliary fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: Present perfect = have/has + past participle. They have finished.

mcQuiz.question: Which auxiliary forms the passive?
mcQuiz.explanation: Passive = be + past participle. The auxiliary 'be' changes form (is, are, was, were, been).

shortQuestions.question: Name the three primary auxiliaries.
shortQuestions.explanation: Primary auxiliaries are be, have, and do. They form tense, passive, questions, and negatives.

shortQuestions.question: In a passive like operations ___ carried out, what type of word fills the gap?
shortQuestions.explanation: Passive needs the auxiliary be. Here, 'are' (plural, present) fits.

shortQuestions.question: Which auxiliary do we use for present simple questions?
shortQuestions.explanation: Present simple questions use do (I/you/we/they) or does (he/she/it).

shortQuestions.question: What form of verb follows a modal (e.g. can ___, should ___)?
shortQuestions.explanation: Modals take the bare infinitive: can go, should book (no 'to').

shortQuestions.question: Does he can or he cans take -s?
shortQuestions.explanation: Modal verbs don't add -s. We say 'he can', not 'he cans'.

shortQuestions.question: Which auxiliary forms the perfect tenses?
shortQuestions.explanation: Have, has, had form present perfect and past perfect.

shortQuestions.question: In the work ___ done yesterday (passive, past), which word fits?
shortQuestions.explanation: Passive past singular: be (was) + past participle. The work was done.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why must the passive auxiliary match the subject and tense?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: The verb must agree with the subject (operations are, the work was). The tense must fit the context (present, past, etc.).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: When do we use do/does/did as an auxiliary?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In present simple and past simple: for questions (Do you know?), negatives (She doesn't like it), and emphasis. We don't use do with other auxiliaries or with be/have (when have = possession).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give two examples of gaps that need a modal verb.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: e.g. you should book early, it would not be possible, they may have left, he can swim.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between must and have to?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Must often expresses obligation from the speaker (I must go). Have to often expresses external rules (You have to wear a seatbelt). Both can fill similar gaps. Have to has forms: has to, had to.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: How do you spot a gap that needs the auxiliary be?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Look for: 1) passive (noun + gap + past participle: operations ___ carried out). 2) Continuous (subject + gap + -ing: she ___ working). The form must match subject and tense.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why don't we say 'he cans' or 'she musts'?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Modal verbs don't take -s in the third person. Can, could, would, will, must, should, may, might are invariable.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What auxiliary fits in ___ you been here before?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Have. Present perfect question: Have you been...? (Have before the subject.).

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Explain the structure of a passive sentence.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Subject + be (in correct form) + past participle. e.g. The letter was written. Operations are carried out. It has been done. The auxiliary be agrees with the subject and shows the tense.
